choices.text: Local treatment with steroids has good results
Treatment of skin condition is essential
Can also present with recurrent corneal ulcers
Can also present with iritis in severe cases

questions.text:
A 65-year-old female patient reports to OPD with complaints of muco-purulent discharge, ocular irritation and lacrimation. Clinical imaging is as depicted below. The patient is being treated for facial acne as well.

Which of the following statements regarding this condition is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of ocular Rosacea: topical steroids may give temporary relief, but overall, local treatment yields disappointing results.

  • Ocular Rosacea often accompanies acne rosacea and presents with conjunctival irritation, lid margin inflammation, and punctate keratitis.
  • Local steroid drops may relieve symptoms briefly, but do not modify disease progression and are not a definitive treatment.
  • Systemic tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline or tetracycline) are more effective in controlling both skin and ocular manifestations. (Option B)
  • Recurrent peripheral corneal ulcers, vascularisation, and even iritis may occur in advanced stages. (Option C, D)

Related Important Points:

  • Tetracycline 250 mg QID or doxycycline 100 mg BID for 3 weeks/month is commonly prescribed.
  • Lid hygiene and tear substitutes may support symptomatic management.
  • Long-term disease control relies on systemic therapy and dermatological care.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with chronic blepharitis presents with mild ocular irritation. On slit-lamp exam, a shallow peripheral corneal ulcer is noted near the limbus with intact epithelium and no stromal involvement. Which of the following organisms is least likely to be associated with this corneal condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pseudomonas is not implicated in marginal catarrhal ulcers; it is associated with severe central ulcers, especially in contact lens users.
  • Marginal corneal ulcers are immune-mediated reactions to staphylococcal toxins, typically seen in patients with chronic lid disease.
  • They are non-infectious and present as peripheral sterile infiltrates with an adjacent clear zone.
  • Other commensals like Moraxella and Haemophilus may be associated with chronic conjunctivitis or lid inflammation.
  • Pseudomonas, in contrast, causes aggressive infectious keratitis, primarily in contact lens users, typically central, rapidly progressive, and purulent.

Related Important Points:

  • Marginal ulcers are usually non-suppurative, with minimal pain and absence of anterior chamber reaction.
  • Respond well to lid hygiene, topical steroids, and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Always differentiate from infective ulcers-clinical features help guide diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

Staphylococcus (Option A): The Most common trigger in marginal keratitis due to immune hypersensitivity against exotoxins in chronic blepharitis.

Moraxella (Option C): Associated with chronic ocular surface inflammation and meibomianitis; contributes to peripheral immune ulceration.

Haemophilus (Option D): Implicated in marginal ulcers via chronic conjunctivitis, particularly in elderly or immunocompromised patients.

choices.text: Hot water fomentation and lid massage

questions.text: What are the treatment options for marginal ulcers?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Management of marginal ulcers involves addressing both lid disease and immune-mediated corneal inflammation through lid hygiene, topical antibiotics, and systemic tetracyclines like doxycycline.

  • Marginal ulcers are typically sterile immune reactions, especially associated with chronic blepharitis or meibomianitis.
  • Lid hygiene (hot compress and massage) helps control the underlying eyelid inflammation. (Option A)
  • Topical broad-spectrum antibiotic ointments like bacitracin-polymyxin reduce surface bacterial load. (Option B)
  • Oral doxycycline (100 mg OD-BD for 2-6 weeks) has anti-inflammatory effects, reduces matrix metalloproteinase activity, and helps in recurrent/resistant cases. (Option C)
  • Short-term topical steroids may be used after controlling infection to reduce corneal vascularisation and inflammation.

Related Important Points:

  • Lesions are shallow, non-infective, and appear near the limbus, often at 2, 4, 7, and 10 o'clock positions.
  • Autoimmune associations may require systemic steroids or cytotoxic agents.
  • Steroids should be avoided until infective components are treated.

questions.text: Which of the following systemic conditions is not associated with deep corneal ulcerations due to antigen-antibody complex formation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Deep peripheral corneal ulceration may occur in autoimmune conditions due to immune complex deposition at the limbus, leading to progressive stromal necrosis and perforation.

  • This is seen in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN), and Wegener's Granulomatosis (GPA). (Option A, B, D)
  • The pathogenesis involves vasculitis and immune complex deposition, leading to marginal or ring ulcers that may progress to total corneal melt.
  • Sarcoidosis, although a systemic granulomatous disorder, typically affects the lacrimal gland, uvea, and retina but is not associated with deep corneal ulceration by immune complex mechanisms.

Related Important Points:

  • Autoimmune corneal melt is a vision-threatening condition requiring systemic immunosuppression.
  • Rheumatology referral is essential in such presentations.
  • Early identification prevents corneal perforation.

choices.text: The Cause of the ulcer is autoimmune destruction of the epithelium

questions.text:
A 37-year-old patient with no significant systemic history reports to OPD with severe pain and lacrimation in both eyes, with clinical imaging as depicted below: corneal ulcers with overhanging edge noted at the periphery in a crescentic manner.

Which of the following statements regarding this condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a classic presentation of Mooren's ulcer, an idiopathic, autoimmune, peripheral ulcerative keratitis characterised by severe pain and marginal corneal ulceration with overhanging edges.

  • The disease is not associated with systemic vasculitis or connective tissue disorders. (Option A)
  • The ulcers rarely perforate, even in severe forms.
  • The base of the ulcer rapidly becomes vascularized, and progression is often relentless in young patients. (Option B, C)
  • Characteristic feature: Crescentic peripheral ulcer with undermined edge and severe pain without scleral involvement.

Related Important Points:

  • The disease may be unilateral (in the elderly, less aggressive) or bilateral (in young adults, "malignant" type).
  • Mooren's ulcer is a diagnosis of exclusion; other autoimmune causes (e.g., RA, GPA) must be ruled out.
  • Management includes topical steroids, immunosuppressants, and in refractory cases, conjunctival resection or lamellar grafting.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with bilateral photophobia, interstitial keratitis, and progressive hearing loss. On slit lamp examination, dull salmon-pink radial vessels are seen in the cornea, with associated conjunctival congestion near the limbus. Which of the following best describes the corneal vascular pattern in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cogan's syndrome presents with both superficial and deep corneal vascularisation, classically described as a "salmon patch" due to deep stromal brush-like vessels.

  • Deep vascularisation is prominent, appearing as dull red due to hazy stroma above.
  • Superficial vessels are present around the limbus but don’t extend centrally.
  • The vessels run in radial brush-like bundles and rarely reach the corneal centre.
  • The condition often begins with interstitial keratitis and progresses to audiovestibular symptoms.

Related Important Points:

  • Systemic manifestations can include aortitis, polyarteritis, and hearing loss.
  • Requires systemic evaluation and may need topical + systemic steroids.
  • Differential includes other causes of interstitial keratitis (e.g., syphilis, TB).

Explanation of other options:

Predominantly superficial (Option A): Superficial vessels occur but do not predominate.

Only deep stromal (Option B): Deep vessels are classic, but superficial ones are also seen.

No vascularisation (Option D): Corneal vascularisation is a key feature-this is incorrect.

choices.text: Corneal lesions heal rapidly with penicillin treatment

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Syphilitic Interstitial Keratitis is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Syphilitic Interstitial Keratitis is a chronic bilateral stromal disease mostly seen in children aged 5-15 years with congenital syphilis. All the listed statements are incorrect.

  • It typically affects children, not older adults. Late-onset keratitis is rare. (Option A ruled out)
  • Healing is slow despite penicillin, as the pathogenesis is immune-mediated, not direct infection. (Option B ruled out)
  • Penetrating keratoplasty in the chronic, healed stage gives good visual outcomes in most cases. (Option C ruled out)

Related Important Points:

  • Disease course is prolonged, corneal clearing may take up to 18 months or longer.
  • Topical steroids, lubricants, and cycloplegics are used to control inflammation and uveitis.
  • Diagnosis relies on serological tests and systemic signs of congenital syphilis.

choices.text: It is a bilateral condition caused by active viral replication
Immune response to viral antigens is the primary mechanism
Involves epithelium with frequent epithelial defects

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents with gradual blurring of vision in one eye without pain. On slit-lamp examination, he has central stromal oedema, keratic precipitates, and no epithelial defect. He had a history of HSV epithelial keratitis two months ago. Which of the following best explains the likely pathophysiology and features of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Disciform keratitis is a non-necrotising immune stromal keratitis caused by hypersensitivity to viral antigens from previous HSV infection.

  • The condition follows prior epithelial keratitis, often caused by HSV.
  • Inflammation is immune-mediated, due to antigen-antibody reactions in the corneal stroma.
  • Epithelial integrity is preserved, unlike epithelial keratitis.
  • Common signs: central disc-shaped stromal oedema, keratic precipitates, Descemet's folds, and decreased corneal sensation.
  • Treated with topical corticosteroids (to reduce immune response) along with oral Acyclovir to prevent viral reactivation.

Related Important Points:

  • Differential includes interstitial keratitis and bacterial stromal ulcers.
  • Topical steroids must not be used without antiviral cover.
  • It can lead to corneal haze and visual impairment if untreated.

Explanation of other options:

It is a bilateral condition caused by active viral replication(Option A): Disciform keratitis is usually unilateral and immune-mediated, not due to live virus.

Involves epithelium with frequent epithelial defects(Option C): Epithelium is intact in disciform keratitis.

Typically associated with Pseudomonas infection(Option D): This describes bacterial keratitis, not disciform.

choices.text: Involves superficial stroma and Bowman's membrane
Opacification is easily treated with topical steroids

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presents with gradual, painless vision loss in one eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals disc-shaped central stromal oedema, Descemet's folds, and an immune ring without any epithelial defect. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Disciform keratitis is a chronic, immune-mediated stromal keratitis involving mid-stroma and Descemet’s membrane, with no ulceration and poor response to treatment.

  • It presents as a central grey disc-like opacity involving mid-stroma, with folds in Descemet's membrane, and often a Wessely immune ring.
  • There is no epithelial ulceration, and corneal anaesthesia may occur.
  • Though topical steroids provide symptomatic relief, permanent stromal scarring often persists despite treatment.
  • It may be associated with mild anterior uveitis and reduced visual acuity due to its central location.

Related Important Points:

  • Always co-administer antivirals to prevent HSV reactivation during steroid use.
  • This condition is non-suppurative and is a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Differentiated from HSV epithelial keratitis, which presents with ulceration.

Explanation of other options:

(A) Involves superficial stroma and Bowman's membrane: It primarily involves the mid to deep stroma and Descemet's membrane.

(B) Ulceration is frequent: Ulceration is not a feature of disciform keratitis; epithelium remains intact.

(C) Opacification is easily treated with topical steroids: While steroids reduce inflammation, opacification often persists and may not fully resolve.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ectatic corneal dystrophy without underlying inflammation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keratectasia is typically a secondary ectasia occurring after corneal surgeries like LASIK and may follow an inflammatory or iatrogenic cause, hence not classified as a dystrophy.

  • Keratoconus, keratoglobus, and pellucid marginal degeneration (PMD) are considered primary, non-inflammatory ectatic dystrophies. (Option A, B ,C)
  • These conditions involve progressive corneal thinning without a preceding inflammatory process.
  • Keratoglobus presents with generalised corneal thinning.
  • PMD is characterised by peripheral thinning, typically inferiorly, with a 'kissing dove' or 'crab claw' pattern on topography.

Related Important Points:

  • Keratectasia is seen as a complication after LASIK in eyes with abnormal corneal biomechanics.
  • Corneal topography is essential for distinguishing between different ectatic disorders.
  • Only the first three options fall under ectatic corneal dystrophies.

questions.text: Which type of astigmatism is most likely associated with keratoconus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keratoconus leads to progressive corneal thinning and protrusion, resulting in irregular myopic astigmatism that cannot be corrected with spectacles.

  • Keratoconus is a progressive ectatic disorder characterised by stromal thinning and apical protrusion.
  • Astigmatism initially appears regular but progresses to irregular as the conical shape worsens.
  • Irregular astigmatism leads to distorted vision and cannot be corrected with standard spherical or cylindrical lenses.
  • Irregular 'scissoring' reflex on retinoscopy and topographic asymmetry confirm the diagnosis.

Related Important Points:

  • Commonly presents in teens or twenties.
  • Associated systemic conditions include Down syndrome and Marfan syndrome.
  • Acute hydrops may develop due to Descemet membrane rupture.
  • Spectacles work only in early disease; rigid gas-permeable lenses or keratoplasty may be needed later.

Explanation of other options:

Regular myopic astigmatism (Option A): Seen in early keratoconus or non-ectatic refractive errors, vision usually improves with glasses.

Regular hypermetropic astigmatism (Option C): Not typically associated with keratoconus.

Irregular hypermetropic astigmatism (Option D): Irregular astigmatism is present, but the refractive shift is toward myopia in keratoconus.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations/results support the diagnosis of keratoconus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diagnosis of keratoconus is supported by clinical signs and investigation findings, including corneal topography, ophthalmoscopic reflexes, and irregular astigmatism on refraction.

  • Corneal topography is highly sensitive for detecting keratoconus and typically shows a cone-shaped protrusion and progressive asymmetric astigmatism(Option A)
  • Ophthalmoscopy from a distance may reveal a central "oil droplet reflex," which is a distortion in the red reflex due to paracentral thinning and conical protrusion(Option B)
  • Refraction reveals increasing irregular myopic astigmatism that cannot be corrected with spectacles alone-this leads to the use of rigid contact lenses in moderate-to-severe cases. (Option C)

Related Important Points:

  • Additional signs include Vogt striae (fine vertical stromal lines) and Fleischer ring (iron deposition around the cone).
  • Keratometry may show steep readings, and Munson's sign (bulging lower lid on downgaze) appears in advanced cases.
  • Early intervention with collagen cross-linking may help halt progression.

questions.text: Where is the maximum corneal thinning (apex of the cone) most commonly located in keratoconus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In keratoconus, the progressive thinning and protrusion of the cornea typically involve the central or paracentral area, with the apex of the cone most often located just inferior to the visual axis. This results in a characteristic inferotemporal steepening pattern on corneal topography.

  • On slit-lamp examination, the conical protrusion appears slightly below the centre.
  • Advanced imaging, such as videokeratography, confirms this inferior displacement.
  • This distinguishes keratoconus from pellucid marginal degeneration, where the thinning is crescentic and located at the inferior limbus.

Related Important Points:

  • Munson's sign (lower lid bulging on downgaze) and oil droplet reflex are seen in advanced cases.
  • Thinning is maximal at the apex of the cone, not at the limbus.
  • Corneal collagen cross-linking is indicated to halt progression, especially when apex thinning and steepening are noted.

Explanation of other options:

At the corneal centre (Option A): Common in early keratoconus but not the most frequent site of apex, usually slightly inferior.

Superior to corneal centre (Option C): Very rare location for cone apex in keratoconus.

Inferior crescentric band at limbus (Option D): Describes pellucid marginal degeneration, not keratoconus.

questions.text: What is iron deposition encircling the cone known as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Fleischer ring is a brownish epithelial iron deposit forming a partial or complete ring at the base of the cone in keratoconus. It is best visualised under cobalt blue light, where it appears as a dark ring due to absorption by hemosiderin within the epithelial cells.

  • Seen in moderate-to-advanced keratoconus cases.
  • Helps differentiate keratoconus from other corneal ectasias.
  • Often used along with other signs like Vogt striae and scissoring reflex on retinoscopy.

Related Important Points:

  • The Fleischer ring is best appreciated under slit-lamp examination using a cobalt blue filter.
  • It is caused by iron deposition (hemosiderin) at the base of the cone.
  • Other hallmark signs of keratoconus include Vogt striae, Munson's sign, and corneal thinning.

Explanation of other options:

Stocker's line (Option B): Iron deposition at the advancing edge of a pterygium.

Ferry's line (Option C): Iron line seen along the edge of a glaucoma filtration bleb.

Hudson-Stähli line (Option D): Age-related horizontal iron line in the lower third of the cornea along the lid closure line.

choices.text: Corneal ectasia is caused due to inflammation
Lower lid notching on downward gaze is called Fleischer's sign
Formation of Vogt striae indicates folds in Descemet's membrane

questions.text:
A 17-year-old male patient reports to OPD with diminution of vision in one eye and frequent changes in glasses with poor visual results. Clinical imaging is shown below.

Which of the following statements regarding this condition is/are correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario is classic for Keratoconus, a non-inflammatory ectatic corneal disorder seen in adolescents or young adults. Key diagnostic features include progressive myopia/astigmatism, inferior corneal thinning, and cone formation.

  • Vogt's striae are fine vertical stress lines seen in the deep stroma and Descemet's membrane, which disappear on pressure and reappear when pressure is released.
  • They indicate mechanical stress and are folds in Descemet's membrane, often seen in moderate to advanced keratoconus.

Related Important Points:

  • Munson sign is the V-shaped notching of the lower lid on downgaze due to corneal protrusion, not to be confused with Fleischer ring.
  • Keratoconus is bilateral in >90% of cases, though asymmetrical.
  • The condition is non-inflammatory in origin and most often idiopathic or associated with eye rubbing, VKC, or systemic syndromes like Down's.

Explanation of other options:

Corneal ectasia due to inflammation (Option A): Keratoconus is a non-inflammatory ectatic disorder.

Other eye involvement is unlikely (Option B): Bilateral involvement is the rule, though asymmetrical.

Fleischer's sign (Option C): Incorrect terminology. The correct sign for lid notching is the Munson sign; the Fleischer ring refers to iron deposition around the base of the cone.

questions.text:
A patient previously diagnosed with keratoconus reports to the OPD with a sudden loss of vision.

Clinical imaging is shown below. What is the next step of management in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation is classical for acute corneal hydrops, a known complication of keratoconus, resulting from a rupture in Descemet's membrane, allowing aqueous to flood the corneal stroma, causing sudden vision loss and corneal oedema.

  • In the acute phase, conservative measures (e.g., hypertonic saline, cycloplegics, patching) may help.
  • However, in advanced or non-resolving cases, the definitive treatment is penetrating keratoplasty, especially if the cornea has scarred or failed to recover.
  • Acute hydrops is typically painful with photophobia and tearing.
  • It may resolve over 6-10 weeks, but scarring often compromises vision.
  • Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) is contraindicated during hydrops-it is used to halt progression before acute decompensation.
  • Contact lenses or spectacles are not effective during this phase due to corneal opacity and oedema.

Explanation of other options:

New spectacle prescription (Option A): Not feasible during acute corneal oedema and visual distortion.

New contact lens prescription (Option B): Contact lenses worsen discomfort during hydrops and cannot correct vision in an opaque cornea.

Collagen cross-linking (Option C): Contraindicated in acute hydrops; done only in progressive KC without Descemet rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Collagen cross-linking is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) is not curative and does not reverse corneal thinning or repair Descemet's membrane ruptures. It is primarily used to halt the progression of keratoconus. (Option A ruled out)

  • The procedure involves UVA (not UV-B) radiation in combination with riboflavin as a photosensitizer. (Option C ruled out)
  • It stabilises the cornea by increasing covalent bonds between collagen fibrils, improving rigidity.
  • It does not reverse corneal thinning, nor does it help in acute hydrops or breaks in Descemet's membrane. (Option B ruled out)

Related Important Points:

  • CXL is best suited for progressive keratoconus before scarring or acute hydrops.
  • Riboflavin 0.1% drops are instilled every 2-3 minutes for 30 minutes after epithelial removal, followed by UVA irradiation.
  • The total energy delivered is typically 5.4 J/cm² using 3 mW/cm² UVA.
  • It can be combined with intracorneal ring segments in certain cases.

choices.text: Penetrating keratoplasty is preferred in all keratoconus cases regardless of Descemet's integrity
DALK has a higher risk of graft rejection than full-thickness keratoplasty
Lamellar keratoplasty can be considered when the endothelium is uninvolved
Keratoplasty should be offered at the initial diagnosis of keratoconus

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding keratoplasty in keratoconus is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Deep Anterior Lamellar Keratoplasty (DALK) is the procedure of choice in keratoconus when the Descemet's membrane and endothelium are unaffected. It preserves the recipient's endothelium and Descemet's membrane, reducing the risk of immune-mediated endothelial graft rejection.

  • Penetrating Keratoplasty (PK) is traditionally performed but carries a higher risk of rejection.
  • DALK avoids full-thickness grafting and is advantageous in early to moderate keratoconus.
  • Keratoplasty is not indicated at diagnosis, but in cases of advanced disease or failed contact lens correction.

Related Important Points:

  • Indications for keratoplasty include significant scarring, poor contact lens tolerance, or acute hydrops complications.
  • DALK avoids endothelial rejection and allows the use of older or lower endothelial-count donor corneas.
  • PK may be needed if Descemet's rupture or hydrops occur.
  • Lamellar techniques have comparable visual outcomes with lower immunologic risk.

Explanation of other options:

Penetrating keratoplasty is preferred in all keratoconus cases (Option A): Not preferred if Descemet's is intact; DALK is safer and effective.

DALK has a higher graft rejection risk (Option B): DALK reduces risk by sparing the host endothelium.

Keratoplasty should be offered at initial diagnosis (Option D): Initial management includes spectacles, contact lenses, and CXL.

choices.text: Hemispherical protrusion of the whole cornea

questions.text: Which of the following is/are not a feature of Keratoglobus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keratoglobus is a non-inflammatory bilateral ectatic disorder characterised by diffuse corneal thinning and a hemispherical protrusion of the cornea (Option A, B). Despite the thinning and protrusion, the cornea typically remains clear, which helps differentiate it from buphthalmos and other ectasias.

  • It is often congenital and can be familial or hereditary.
  • The IOP remains normal, the optic disc shows no cupping, and the anterior chamber angle is normal. (Option C)
  • Refractive error is typically "with-the-rule" astigmatism.

Related Important Points:

  • Keratoglobus is usually bilateral and diagnosed early due to the globe's appearance.
  • Differentiated from buphthalmos by clear cornea and absence of glaucoma.
  • The thinning is generalised rather than paracentral as in keratoconus.
  • There is an increased risk of corneal rupture, even with minor trauma.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are not likely associated with pellucid marginal degeneration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pellucid Marginal Degeneration (PMD) is a bilateral, non-inflammatory ectatic disorder characterised by a narrow band of inferior corneal thinning, usually in the 4 to 8 o'clock position. It is asymptomatic and painless (Option A), with no signs of inflammation or vascularisation.

  • The epithelium remains intact, and there is no anterior chamber reaction.
  • The cornea just above the area of thinning becomes ectatic, resulting in against-the-rule myopic astigmatism.
  • Hydrops may occur, but the disease usually progresses very slowly, unlike keratoconus. (Option C)

Related Important Points:

  • PMD is often mistaken for keratoconus due to the irregular astigmatism.
  • It lacks corneal vascularisation, unlike inflammatory ectasias like Terrien's marginal degeneration. (Option B)
  • Differentiation from other ectasias is critical for planning interventions like CXL or keratoplasty.

questions.text: A 2-year-old malnourished child presents with bilateral corneal melting following an episode of measles. On examination, >2/3 of the corneal surface is necrotic, dull, insensitive, and vascularized. What is the most appropriate WHO stage classification of xerophthalmia for this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keratomalacia represents an ocular emergency caused by severe Vitamin A deficiency, especially in malnourished children. WHO classifies xerophthalmia stages based on site and severity:

  • X3A: Ulceration or melting involving <1/3 of the corneal surface
  • X3B: Ulceration or melting involving >1/3 of the corneal surface

Related Important Points:

  • Typically bilateral, rapid onset, and painless due to sensory loss
  • Commonly precipitated by systemic infections like measles or pneumonia
  • Often leads to permanent blindness and high mortality if untreated
  • Requires immediate high-dose Vitamin A and supportive therapy

Explanation of other options:

X2 (Option A): Corneal dryness without ulceration or necrosis, earlier stage.

X3A (Option B): Corneal ulceration limited to <1/3 of cornea, milder form.

X4 (Option D): Corneal scarring, healed stage, not active keratomalacia.

choices.text: Single dose of Vitamin A 1 lac IU
Three doses of Vitamin A 1 lac IU
Single dose of Vitamin A 2 lac IU
Three doses of Vitamin A 2 lac IU

questions.text: What is the dosage schedule of Vitamin A for a 14-month-old baby diagnosed with keratomalacia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin A deficiency leading to keratomalacia is an ophthalmic emergency, particularly in malnourished children under 5 years of age.

The WHO-recommended dosage for children ≥12 months with keratomalacia is:

  • 200,000 IU orally at diagnosis
  • 200,000 IU on the next day
  • 200,000 IU on the 14th day
  • For children <6 months, the dose is 50,000 IU.
  • For 6-12 months, it is 100,000 IU.
  • If oral intake is not possible, intramuscular water-miscible Vitamin A can be used at half the oral dose.

Explanation of other options:

Single dose of 1 lakh IU (Option A): Inadequate and incorrect schedule for treatment.

Three doses of 1 lakh IU (Option B): Recommended for 6–12 months old; not sufficient for a 14-month-old child.

Single dose of 2 lakh IU (Option C): Only initial part of the full regimen; incomplete management.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is/are associated with exposure keratopathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Exposure keratopathy occurs when the cornea is incompletely covered by the eyelids, leading to desiccation and epithelial breakdown.

  • It is most commonly caused by lagophthalmos (incomplete lid closure), which may be due to facial nerve palsy or mechanical causes. (Option A)
  • Exophthalmos, as seen in thyroid eye disease, can prevent full lid closure, contributing to corneal exposure. (Option B)
  • Facial nerve palsy results in orbicularis oculi dysfunction and neuroparalytic keratopathy, which leads to poor blinking and incomplete eye closure. (Option C)
  • The exposed corneal epithelium becomes dry, leading to punctate epithelial erosions, stromal melting, and even perforation if untreated.

Related Important Points:

  • Common signs: Inferior corneal staining, punctate epithelial keratopathy, stromal haze, or melting.
  • Associated symptoms: Dryness, irritation, foreign body sensation, especially on waking.
  • In advanced cases: Corneal ulceration, infectious keratitis, or secondary bacterial infection.
  • Management depends on severity: Artificial tears, bandage contact lenses, tarsorrhaphy, or gold lid implants in facial palsy.

choices.text: Occurs due to paralysis of CN5, the trigeminal nerve
Occurs due to paralysis of CN-7 Facial nerve

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Neurotrophic keratopathy is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neurotrophic keratopathy is caused by loss of trigeminal (CN V) innervation to the cornea, not by facial nerve palsy or Acanthamoeba infection.

  • CN V (ophthalmic division) supplies sensory innervation to the cornea; its damage leads to corneal anaesthesia and impaired healing. (Option A)
  • CN VII palsy leads to exposure keratopathy due to lagophthalmos, not neurotrophic changes. (Option B ruled out)
  • Acanthamoeba causes infectious keratitis, unrelated to nerve dysfunction. (Option C ruled out)

Related Important Points:

  • Neurotrophic keratopathy presents in stages:
    • Stage 1: Irregular epithelium, punctate staining.
    • Stage 2: Persistent epithelial defect with thickened edges.
    • Stage 3: Stromal melting ± secondary infection.
  • Causes include herpes simplex/zoster, surgical ablation of the trigeminal ganglion, diabetes, tumours, and stroke.
  • Treatment includes lubricants, therapeutic contact lenses, cenegermin (rhNGF), and tarsorrhaphy in advanced stages.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are treatment options for Neurotrophic Keratitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neurotrophic keratitis is managed with ocular surface protection strategies, including eye shields, punctal occlusion, and tarsorrhaphy, depending on severity.

  • Eye shield provides physical protection for the desensitised cornea and reduces further trauma during healing. (Option A)
  • Punctal occlusion conserves the tear film by reducing drainage, helpful in associated dry eye. (Option B)
  • Lateral tarsorrhaphy (temporary or permanent) reduces the palpebral fissure and protects the cornea in advanced disease stages or recurrent ulceration. (Option C)

Related Important Points:

  • Loss of trigeminal (CN V) innervation leads to corneal anaesthesia, persistent epithelial defects, and stromal ulceration.
  • Other modern treatments include:
    • Cenegermin (rhNGF eye drops) - promotes corneal healing.
    • Amniotic membrane grafts or bandage contact lenses for epithelial support.
  • Neurotization surgery for restoration of corneal innervation in advanced cases.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with recurrent bilateral redness, burning, and foreign body sensation predominantly involving the superior bulbar conjunctiva. She also reports episodes of photophobia and mild discharge. Slit-lamp examination shows punctate epithelial staining of the superior cornea and the presence of fine filaments. What feature is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Superior Limbic Keratoconjunctivitis (SLKC) is a chronic bilateral condition characterised by superior bulbar and tarsal conjunctival inflammation and filamentary keratopathy.

  • SLKC occurs more commonly in females, is typically bilateral, and is often associated with thyroid dysfunction. (Option A)
  • Corneal filaments, superior punctate epithelial keratopathy, and superior pannus formation are key findings. (Option C, D)
  • The diagnosis is supported by Rose Bengal and fluorescein staining
  • Unilateral presentation is uncommon and not characteristic of SLKC, hence ruled out.

Related Important Points:

  • The exact cause is unknown, but chronic mechanical trauma and tear film abnormalities play a role.
  • Often associated with hyperthyroidism or thyroid eye disease.
  • Long-standing cases may show exacerbations and remissions.
  • Management includes:
    • Frequent use of lubricating eye drops
    • Acetylcysteine drops for filament dissolution
    • Antibiotic ointments for associated blepharitis
  • Punctal occlusion in severe dryness
